article.title: Cosolute partitioning in polymer networks: Effects of flexibility and volume transitions

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the mean network volume (normalized by the volume of a stiff and repulsive reference network) as a function of the solvent quality parameter for various network bending rigidities. Which statement best describes the observed trend?
choices: Increasing the network bending rigidity always leads to a larger volume, regardless of the solvent quality.
For a given solvent quality, increasing the network bending rigidity generally leads to a smaller volume.
The network volume always increases with increasing solvent quality parameter.
The presence of cosolutes has a negligible impact on the network volume.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure depicts the mean network monomer density profiles (packing fraction) for flexible and semi-flexible polymers at various solvent qualities. What does the transition from a structured shape with multiple peaks to a single broad peak signify?
choices: A decrease in the solvent quality parameter.
The network transitioning from a collapsed state to a swollen state.
The network transitioning from a swollen state to a collapsed state.
An increase in the cosolute concentration inside the network.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure displays a state diagram for a semi-flexible network film, showcasing the mean width as a function of both the solvent quality and cosolute coupling parameters. What new phenomenon is observed in the presence of cosolutes, besides the intrinsic volume transition?
choices: Cosolute-induced swelling, where cosolutes cause the network to swell even in bad solvent conditions.
Cosolute-induced collapse, where strong cosolute attraction to the monomers can collapse the network even in good solvent conditions.
Cosolute-independent collapse, where cosolutes have no impact on the volume transition of the network.
Cosolute-induced dissolution, where high cosolute concentrations lead to the complete dissolution of the network.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure showcases the adsorption energy profile as a function of both solvent quality and cosolute coupling parameters for flexible and semi-flexible networks. What does a negative value of the adsorption energy (Î”G) indicate?
choices: Cosolutes are preferentially excluded from the network.
Cosolutes are preferentially absorbed into the network.
The network is transitioning from a swollen state to a collapsed state.
The network is transitioning from a collapsed state to a swollen state.
